For the eager readers, feel free to scroll down to the code section.

Neural Style Transfer (NST) is a technique that involves the utilization of deep convolutional neural network and algorithms to extract the content information from an image and the style information from another reference image. After the extraction of style and content, a combination image is generated where the content and style of the resulting image is sourced from different images.
NST is a method of image stylization, which is a process that involves using an input reference image to provide an output image with variance in style derived from the input image.
NST technique was presented in the paper “A Neural Algorithm of Artistic Style” by Leon A Gatys et al.

Deep neural network(DNN), more specifically, Convolutional neural network (CNN) have a crucial characteristic, which is the ability to learn the spatial representation of content and style within images. This characteristic enables the NST technique to be achievable.

The spatial representation of the input image generated by CNNs captures the image’s statistical information of the style and content. NST combines the extracted style and content into a generated output image.
The activation function in the intermediary layers within a CNN layer structure provides the capability of capturing content and style statistical information of the input image.

CNN layers output a feature map after the convolution operation that involves having a filter slide over the input image. The content of an image is actually within the generated feature map of each layer.
Extracting content from the feature maps of the intermediary layers will provide high level structural and geometrical information of the input image.

The feature maps obtain the style of the input image. To derive the style of an image, it is required to evaluate the mean and correlation of the feature maps in the intermediary layers. The information provided by this process provides textural pattern information of the input image.

In order to successfully implement the process of Neural Style Transfer using two reference images, we’ll be leveraging modules on TensorFlow Hub
TensorFlow hub provides a suite of reusable machine learning components such as datasets, weights, models, etc.
For the implementation section of this article, we will be utilizing a bunch of tools and libraries for loading images and performing data transformation.
First, we will import the tools and libraries required.
Next, we declare two variables that hold the directory path to images for the content and style of our output result. Also, we will display the images.
It is required that the images are converted into a tensor representation. For this next step, we will leverage TensorFlow’s image processing methods.

We’ll create a function that takes in the image path, then converts the images into a tensor using ‘tf.io.read_file’. We proceed further to change the data types of the values in the tensor to floats between 0 and 1 using ‘tf.image.decode_image’.
An implementation of the opposite of the above is required to visualize the result from the TensorFlow Hub module. We need to convert the tensor returned to an image we can visualize.

We simply denormalize the tensor that contains values between 0 and 1 to actual pixel values by multiplying each element by 255. The next step is to create an array using Numpy that includes the appropriate data type we require.
We return an image object from the tensor.

Now we’ll convert the images to tensor and pass them to a module via the ‘.load()’ the method from the TensorFlow Hub package.
We expect a combined result of the style and content from our reference image; therefore, we will create a variable to hold the result of the operation from the module.
To visualize the result, we simply utilize the ‘tensor_to_image’ function we created earlier.
We have managed to combine the style and content of two reference images and generated a mesh image.
